channel.title: NYT > International Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gabriel García Márquez’s Archive Goes to University of Texas
item.description: The archive of Gabriel García Márquez has been acquired by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas and includes manuscripts, notebooks, photos, correspondence and personal artifacts related to his important books.
item.category: Ransom, Harry, Center, The University of Texas at Austin
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER SCHUESSLER

item.title: In North Dakota, Rising Unease Over Oil’s Effects
item.description: After an unusual land deal, a giant spill and a tanker-train explosion, anxiety began to ripple across the North Dakota prairie.
item.dc:creator: By DEBORAH SONTAG

item.title: Climate Change Threatens to Strip the Identity of Glacier National Park
item.description: In a century, the number of glaciers in Montana’s Glacier National Park, on the Canadian border, has dropped to about 25 from 150.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES

item.title: Marion S. Barry Jr.: ‘A Complicated Man’ Whose Legacy Recounts Both Greatness and Blunders
item.description: Mr. Barry was a man venerated, disgraced and redeemed in a political career that spanned four decades and included four terms as mayor and six months in prison on drug charges.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW SIDDONS and EMMARIE HUETTEMAN
item.media:description: Marion S. Barry Jr. campaigning in 1994, four years after his drug arrest.

item.title: Memo From Europe: Nations Ponder How to Handle European Fighters Returning From Jihad
item.description: A young man who came back to Germany from fighting in Syria has confessed in court and said he would like “to live a totally normal life.”
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: German officials have shielded the full identity of Kreshnik B., left, who confessed to fighting in Syria with the Islamic State.

item.title: Workers in Silicon Valley Weigh In on Obama’s Immigration Order
item.description: Despite drawbacks, some immigrants working in technology said the president’s actions could make work in the United States easier.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL
item.media:description: Laks Srini, the chief technology officer at Zenefits, who is from India, has been unable to upgrade his visa to reflect his role.

item.title: Rand Paul Calls for a Formal Declaration of War Against ISIS
item.description: Mr. Paul, a likely presidential candidate who has emerged as one of the Republican Party’s most cautious voices on military intervention, offered a very circumscribed definition of war.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, offered a proposal that would limit the duration of military action to one year.

item.title: Despite Persecution, Guardian of Lake Tai Spotlights China’s Polluters
item.description: Despite pressure from Beijing, factories continue to dump toxic waste into waterways because the cost of violating the rules is lower than the cost of compliance.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sting to Join the Cast of His Broadway Musical
item.description: Sting, who wrote the music and lyrics for the struggling Broadway musical “The Last Ship,” will join the cast on Dec. 9.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK HEALY
item.media:credit: Jacob Blickenstaff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sting and Jeffrey Seller, left, lead producer of “The Last Ship,” told performers Sunday that Sting is joining the cast, replacing Jimmy Nail, right.

item.title: Iran Grants Bail to Woman From Britain Held 5 Months
item.description: Ghoncheh Ghavami, 25, who has dual citizenship, is appealing a one-year sentence for a conviction that has been linked to activism.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Graft Hobbles Iraq’s Military in Fighting ISIS
item.description: The Iraqi military and police forces had been so pillaged by their own leadership that they all but collapsed this spring in the face of the advancing Islamic State fighters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Iraqi Army member reporting to be reinstated for duty in September, after many deserted in the face of the ISIS onslaught.

item.title: In Delhi, Pushing Through the Wall (of Air Pollution)
item.description: Despite very high levels of air pollution in India’s capital city, the Delhi half-marathon is one of a growing number of running races across the country.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Runners passing the India Gate in the Delhi half-marathon Sunday. India has had a recent increase in running races.

item.title: Tunisia Vote for Leader Likely to Go to a Runoff
item.description: Beji Caid Essebsi, a former prime minister, and Moncef Marzouki, the interim president, were leading but neither expected to win a majority.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: A polling station in Tunis, the capital, on Sunday. Beji Caid Essebsi, a former prime minister, and Moncef Marzouki, the interim president, were leading in Tunisia’s first free presidential election.

item.title: Retro Report: Debate Persists Over Diagnosing Mental Health Disorders, Long After ‘Sybil’
item.description: After the book and film “Sybil” were released, diagnoses of multiple personality disorder skyrocketed. Was it more awareness by doctors, or overdiagnosis?
item.dc:creator: By CLYDE HABERMAN

item.title: Science Times: A Lifesaving Transplant for Coral Reefs
item.description: A quick-grow laboratory technique, called microfragmenting, may make it possible to mass-produce reef-building corals for transplanting onto dead or dying reefs that took centuries to develop.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD MORIN
item.media:description: A mountainous star coral colony that was grown from an inch-square fragment cut a year earlier off of a parent colony.

item.title: Indianapolis Star Newspaper Apologizes for Cartoon on Migrants
item.description: The Star removed a cartoon from its website after readers complained the drawing was racist for depicting an immigrant family climbing through a window to crash a white family’s Thanksgiving dinner.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: Iran Nuclear Negotiators, Facing Key Differences, Weigh Extending Deadline
item.description: Western and Iranian officials said on Sunday that with issues still unresolved on an agreement to curb Iran’s nuclear program, they might consider prolonging the talks beyond Monday.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students demonstrating in front of Tehran's only nuclear test reactor.

item.title: With ‘Hunger Games’ Campaigns, Lionsgate Punches Above Its Weight
item.description: In its campaigns for the “Hunger Games” films, Lionsgate’s tiny marketing department has used mastery of social media and a culture of risk-taking to dazzle the legacy studios.
item.dc:creator: By BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: Jennifer Lawrence, star of the "Hunger Games" films, was prepped for a photo shoot in January to market the latest entry in the series.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Dragon Age: Inquisition Evokes Interactive Storytelling
item.description: Dragon Age: Inquisition shows that sophisticated storytelling in video games has become commonplace even as it remains the most experimental and contentious aspect of the medium.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS SUELLENTROP
item.media:description: Games like Dragon Age: Inquisition increasingly incorporate interactive stories.

item.title: Beyoncé ‘Platinum Edition’ Adds New Songs and Remixes
item.description: Beyoncé has repackaged her latest hit album with two new songs and four remixes, as well as a live DVD and a calendar.
item.dc:creator: By BEN SISARIO

item.title: Survivors Pulled From Ruins After Quake in Japan
item.description: A magnitude-6.7 quake near the city of Nagano injured at least 40 people, damaged dozens of buildings and forced hundreds into emergency shelters.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Police officers patrolled on Sunday near damaged houses in the ski resort town of Hakuba, where some of the worst damage occurred.

item.title: Afghanistan Quietly Lifts Ban on Nighttime Raids
item.description: The government of President Ashraf Ghani has cleared the way for special forces raids, blocked by former President Hamid Karzai, to resume in 2015.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.media:description: Soldiers of the 101st Airborne Division after a night raid in Yahya Khel, Paktika Province, in February 2011. A subsequent ban on night raids under the Karzai administration has been lifted by the new Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani.

item.title: Blast at Game Kills Dozens in Afghanistan
item.description: Explosives were detonated in a crowd gathered to watch a game between a village team and players from a neighboring district in Paktika Province.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Marion Barry, Washington’s ‘Mayor for Life,’ Even After Prison, Dies at 78
item.description: Mr. Barry was a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of the nation’s capital who went to prison on a cocaine charge and then made one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID STOUT

item.title: Formula One: Hamilton Takes Formula One Title Over Rosberg
item.description: Lewis Hamilton clinched his second Formula One title with victory at the season-ending Abu Dhabi Grand Prix on Sunday, with his rival Nico Rosberg finishing far behind.
item.dc:creator: By BRAD SPURGEON
item.media:description: Lewis Hamilton was greeted by his partner Nicole Scherzinger, family and friends after clinching the Formula One championship with a victory in the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix.
